agent_utterance: Backup snack options: 1) 1 small apple + 1 tablespoon peanut butter (about 150–170 kcal; provides protein and fiber). 2) 1/2 cup edamame (steamed) with a few cherry tomatoes (about 100–130 kcal; good protein and fiber). Quick non-food coping ideas for evenings: - Do a 3-minute cooling breath: inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 6 counts, repeat 3–5 times, and name 5 things you see to ground yourself. - Hydrate and cool down: sip cold water or peppermint tea, and splash a little cold water on your face. - Move for 5 minutes: gentle stretch or a short hallway walk to shift cravings. - Establish a calm wind-down: a brief 5-minute body scan or journaling, then dim lights and unplug screens 30 minutes before bed.

I appreciate the plan. A couple of additions would help on tougher nights: Urge journaling prompts I can use tonight include: 1) What physical hunger am I really feeling right now—am I hungry or seeking comfort? 2) What emotion or situation is driving the urge? 3) What small, kind action could I try instead of eating? 4) If I do snack, what portion would truly meet hunger and how will I pause afterward? Protein-rich late-snack options (about 150–200 kcal): 1) 1/2 cup cottage cheese with 1/2 cup berries; 2) 1 hard-boiled egg with cucumber slices or a small apple; 3) 1 string cheese plus a small apple; 4) 1/2 cup plain Greek yogurt with 1 tablespoon almond butter. Gentle check-in reminders: a quick 2‑minute mood/hunger log at a set time (e.g., check in at 8:30 pm), noting hunger level (0–10), mood, and one kind action for the next hour; or set a calendar/app reminder to log feelings after dinner. I feel hopeful about this approach and I’ll log tonight to adjust tomorrow.

agent_utterance: Great question. Add these simple non-food fallbacks for social, travel, and late-night moments: 1) 5-4-3-2-1 grounding + urge journaling: name 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste, then jot a one-line note about the urge. 2) Quick distraction: 5-minute puzzle, a short hallway walk, or a 2-minute text check-in with a friend. 3) Hydration and sensory reset: sip cold water or peppermint tea; splash cold water on your face. 4) Social/travel approach: suggest a non-food activity with others (a quick walk, a light game, or a caffeine-free drink) and have a buddy to check in. 5) Late-night wind-down: start a 15-minute routine (brush teeth, wash face, dim lights, light stretching, a quick journaling line) and set a firm bedtime. Check-in cue: schedule an 8:30 pm mood/hunger log with one kind action for the next hour. If you slip, log honestly and adjust portions or timing.
